body.p: Using the probabilities you found in Question 2:
Let X represent a discrete random variable that counts the number of incorrect identifications. Create the probability distribution.

part.hint: Since there are 3 trials, X can be 0, 1, 2, or 3.
Count the number of Is in each of the elements in the sample space and use their probabilities to create the distribution.

explanation.p: Notice that one of the elements of the sample space has 0 Is, some have 1 I, some have 2 Is, and one has 3 Is.
When X = 0 we have CCC. Thus, P(X = 0) = 0.512.
When X = 1 we have ICC, CIC, and CCI. All of these had the same probability. Thus, P(X = 1) = 3(0.128), or 0.384.
When X = 2, we have IIC, ICI, and CII. All of these had the same probability. Thus, P(X = 2) = 3(.032) or 0.096.
Last, when X = 3, we have III. Thus, P(X = 3) = 0.008.
The sum of these probabilities is indeed 1: 0.512 + 0.384 + 0.096 + 0.008 = 1.
This is summarized in the table below:

content.p: Now we wish to find some probabilities using the probability distribution you just created.

body.p: Find P(at least one identification is incorrect).

part.hint: At least one means one or more. What values of X are one or more?
At least one means is X is 1, 2, or 3. In other words, X ≥ 1.

explanation.p: At least one means P(X ≥ 1). So X can be 1, 2, or 3. This means the probability is 0.384 + 0.096 + 0.008 = 0.488.
Using complements P(X ≥ 1) = 1 = P(X = 0) or 1 - 0.512, which is also 0.488.

question.body: Find P(more than 2 identifications are incorrect).

part.hint: What values for X are more than 2?
The only value for X that is more than 2 is 3.
part.explanation: The only value for X that is more than 2 is 3. P(X = 3) = 0.008.

question.body: Find P(no more than one identification is incorrect).

part.hint: What values for X are not more than 1?
The values for X that are no more than 1 are 0 and 1.

explanation.p: The values for X that are no more than one are 0 and 1.
P(no more than one identification is incorrect) = P(X = 0) + P(X = 1) = 0.512 + 0.384, or 0.896.
